I chose the chocolate cake, whipped cream, and melted hershey one and it wasn't sweet at all.  I was soo good and light but it was pretty damn filling.  It's conveniently folded into a flat cone and placed into a custom made paper cone thingy.  My boyfriend ordered the nutella one and added peanut butter and whipped cream.  That was my first time trying nutella and I don't know if it was the crepes or the nutella flavor but I can tell you one thing:  From now on whenever I eat nutella I'm going to expect an orgy in my mouth!  Haha... sorry if that was too vulgar.  Seriously, though!  Holy cow!  Nuff said.  He bit into the little piece of parchment paper wrapped between the crepe and inside the paper cone.  Could've been because it was the same texture as the crepe... could've been because it was soo damn good.  Either way, I'm sure braddah would've eaten his fingers off if it wasn't such a generous serving.  

I never really craved or enjoyed it before but I don't think I'll ever be able to eat crepes the same again.  Not only am I not a fan but Genki f**ked me up now because when I DO want crepes, it'll have to be Genki's!!
author: Almalei M.

description: I love me a crispy crepe. This place offers a lot of options and a super crispy shell kind of like a waffle cone just made off the iron before it fully dries. I had a simple green tea ice cream with whip and it was basically an orgasm in my mouth. Also picked up a pack of Haribo mini frogs here.  awesome find
author: Dominic C.

description: The ice cream here is yummy! I'm not a huge fan of crepes as I can never finish the whole thing myself.  I like the lychee and strawberry ice cream.  The shop sells ice cream, crepes, boba drinks, snacks, toys and Japanese products.  I will be back to try their other ice cream flavors.
author: Jennie W.

description:
Genki just doesn't compare to Sophie's, but in times of desperation and ridiculous carb/sugar/fat cravings, this will do the trick. I remember coming here in high school and seeing a pigeon flying loose in the store while the crepe-makers were just chillen, making the crepes like there wasn't a rabies-infested creature causing a ruckus in their store. Hahaha good times, Genki. Good times.

Love that I can get me some Asian snacks, car fresheners, random plush things, and crepes all in the same place.
author: Moraia W.

description:
Uber yummy!  OMFG! This is the shizzle!  

Genki brings the kid out of me.  No, I don't talk like that, and yes it took me a minute to think of some contemporary slang that kids now a day's say (or may not).  I had a few others, but elected to leave them out.  

Tightly pocketed, the crepes are made masterfully in front of you.  The kitchen if one may call it that is open for all to see.  If you've never seen it, go ahead and watch a professional in progress.  For some reason, it looks like it's been the same group of guys making the crepes for years.  

The wait time for your crepe depends on how busy it is.  Wait time may be up to three minutes or so (from my experience at least).  Don't fret though because this place also has a mini mart full of Asian snacks and knick-knacks to browse through.  My sister brought this to my attention recently, they have these bags of seaweed chips (forgot the name) that have a variety of flavors like tempera and spicy.  I would recommend if only I remembered the name.

As far as your choice of crepe, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  For me, if there's nutella in it, I'm set.  Nutella is the key.  Usually your favorite fruit in the crepe will make magic for you.  If you're not a fan of fruit, just have it with ice cream and nutella with some whip cream.  

The crepes come in a paper holder and a spoon.  The holder is merely for hygiene purposes in my eyes.  What a simple product the Genki crepe, but it's prepared so deliciously.  Genki makes one of the best I've had.  Hands down!  Fo Sho!  (again...I don't talk like that.)
author: Arnold T.

description:
A big fan!  After a big meal you can find me wanting a dessert especially if I am in the city since I don't frequest it often living in East Coco County.  I actually asked my husband if we could go to Sophie's Crepes the only crepe spot I know in japantown which is known for having a huge line.  My hub mentioned it to his father that we wanted crepes for dessert and told us about Genki!  We all met there.  And I was so excited because first of all NO LINE, and it was a cute little store that had candies, and sanrio type stuff as well goodies from candy to drinks.  WOuld definitely love to go back!

I sort of made my own Crepe: It was pretty loaded.  I had vanilla and green tea ice cream, cut up strawberries and bananas as well as whip cream and chocolate syrup.  I was in heaven!!!
author: Rachel R.

description:
Located across the street from Burma Superstar, coming for Genki Crepes after dinner was a given. But having built them up for 1.5+ years since I first visited, my most recent visit to Genki Crepes was a bit of a let down ... and after just having Sophie's Crepes not too long ago, I couldn't help but to compare the two. 

Maybe I was overly stuffed from dinner and had no room for dessert, but I didn't find our crepe all that memorable. We had evidently ordered the exact same crepe as our first visit - strawberries, custard, no nutella??!, lychee ice cream, and whipped cream. The crepe itself was a bit *too* crispy, giving away to no chewiness. Overly crispiness could have probably been remidied with some vocalization and monitoring... but that what switched me off from Genki - though my boyfriend loved it! The lychee ice cream was overly icy and left me longing for the gelato from Sophies. The custard was also more like the cream on top of asian fruit tarts than egg pudding - which was what I was expecting, though I guess thats not something to knock them down for? IDK; maybe my expectations were too high... but I think I prefer Sophie's Crepes to Genki's... not to say I won't stop by again the next time I make my rounds at Burma Superstar.

Worth noting, my boyfriend says he likes Genki's better than Sophie's... so I guess its all down to preference.
author: Lana N.

description: This place is your go to for your sweet tooth. Do you want Japanese import candy? Done. Boba? Done. Egg puffs? done. There's a $10 credit card limit so I usually find that my boba and egg puffs are accompanied by a bunch of candy to hit my limit...I mean I have to.
author: Genevieve L.

description:
Mixed Fruit Nutella w/ whipped cream for $4.75.... soooo good! Crispy crepe with fresh fruits.

They have both savory and dessert crepes, ice cream, and tapioca drinks. Their selection of Asian snacks is extensive and not as pricey as I thought it would be.

A lot of young people at this location but the line usually moves fast. Bench seating only!
author: Tina T.

description:
Decent crepes and the asian super market is fun to roam around if you aren't getting any food. 

The place is usually pretty busy and that scaffold has been over the store front for a while. It took me a very long time to find this place the first time I went.
author: Glenda L.

description:
"If it ain't broken, don't fix it." My exact feelings when it comes to the classic nutella + vanilla ice cream crepe aka #1 on the menu. So simple yet so full of taste and flavor! For just about $5 and just a few minutes you get a crepe filled to the brim with classic vanilla surrounded by sweet sweet nutella. My gf and I walked the aisles combing for cool/cute items to entertain ourselves with as we took turns devouring our crepe. 

Truly a great stop when you've got a dessert craving and aren't sure what to get! Alright, so I guess I lied at the beginning; add bananas to make your nutella+ice cream experience even better!

Remember that under $10 is cash only! But with all the amazing items on the menu and cool stuff throughout the back of the store that minimum is always easily reached! Check this place out and enjoy! You'll find me back here soon!
author: Jon K.

description:
Here's what you do:

Go out for dinner in the hood (May I suggest Mandalay?). Have a couple of drinks and just enough food that you probably don't need to eat more, but the alcohol tells you that you definitely want to eat more. 

Head over to Genki. Order a crepe. Order a crazy-cheesecake-and-ice-cream-filled one if you've had 3 or more drinks, order the simple nutella version if you've had only a beer or two. While you wait, delight in Genki's truly awesome assortment of imported Asian treats (I purchased some ultra-dark chocolate). 

Once given your humongous crepe, eat, and enjoy. 

Then walk over to a neighborhood bar, rinse and repeat. 

------------------------

In all seriousness, this place is A-ok. The crepes were tasty and quickly made to order. They were cheap, and so was the rest of their snack selection. They don't really have a great waiting area (just a few benches), but that's ok: it's clear this a talk-and-walk kind of snack. 

Low five.
author: Allison S.

description:
Let me just say, every time I think of crepes GENKIS is the first and only thing that pops into my head but sadly I live too far to enjoy it. I had my first experience at GENKIS on my first trip to SF and boy was I glad my friends introduced me to this place. The first time I got the cheesecake and chocolate ice cream combo and boy was it ever so delicious and one of my friends got the strawberry ice cream with kiwis. Yum! My mouth salivates as I write this review. I can't wait til I get to go back to try the other delicious combos and perhaps make one of my own. 

Btw, this place gets packed but don't let that stray you because it definitely is worth it :D
author: Erin L.

description:
Can't believe I never left a review for Genki!

My fave crepes by far. It's a small shop like a mini mart of asian snacks and such and the corner for crepes! The only downfall is there's not much sitting area for eating your crepes and other goodies besides two benches inside and another outside. If you come on a rainy day, that 2nd bench inside basically gets hit by the rain for the most part.

I always get the nutella with lychee and i ask for green tea ice cream The bomb!
author: Annissa H.

description:
As I've stated before, I'm not good at dim sum on Clement.  I'm better at looking at a girl's pipes and diagnosing UTI, prescribing cranberry juice and then touching up my mascara.  After a grubbing dim sum session that resembled a sausage stuffing party on chaunnakka, and a short trip to the grocery for ground meat, I convinced the BF to accompany me here for a quick crepes.  Just one.  

I wanted to try something sweet with more sweetness and ice cream.  I was hoping for something like crepes suzette.  But it was not to be had.  

There were some hi-chew candies that cost $2.  Was it because it was directly imported from Japan?  Now that the island is practically obliterated, these candies will become hot commodities.  

I wanted the green tea with lychee but the BF wanted mango with strawberries.  The crepes I was handed was very very thin.  The edges were crisp and almost fortune cookie tasting.  The middle was softer and mealier.  The mango ice cream was creamy.  Not very flavorful.  I would have liked it to have more mango-goodness.  More flavor.  Even fake flavor.  Or super sweet.  SOMETHING!  Give me something huge and explosive, right in the mouth.  

The sugared strawberries at the bottom was better, sweeter, more mouth-gasm.  I also had a wicked thirst.  It prevented me from tasting things.  I wish my mouth was younger, more nimble, supple, elastic.  I want to be YOUNG AGAIN.
author: Christina C.

description:
I finally had a crepe here and boy, they're well worth the wait. This place was busy even on a Monday night. Some guy in line couldn't get over how crowded it was, so much that he started saying, "It's like a rave in here" and started making the techno music noise. What a character.

We split the Vanilla and Nutella one which was more than enough for both of us. My friend from out of town got a banana and nutella which she also enjoyed. Yummy goodness. I will definitely be patronizing Genki in the future, you can count on that.

An added bonus, you can browse toys and other cool goodies as well.
author: Amy J.

description:
I truly wish that I could be like the hundreds of ya'll who have been blessed with a delicious crepe to later commend on yelp. Sadly, it just couldn't be done the day I got mine. 

The menu was pretty overwhelming so I asked the chef to give me his recommendation-- hit me with your best shot, I ain't allergic to anything! What I got was the cheesecake and blueberry crepe. Sounds appetizing right!? Er..... If I could compare it to anything, the consistency of the crepe had my tongue feeling like it was on a slip n' slide WITH NO WATER. The blueberry sauce didn't help with the lubrication process either. The cheesecake pasted over my tounge like peanut butter~gross. My overall crepe was unbearably sweet and dry...blah. Maybe I'll come by this place again and try another item-with ice cream or something!
author: Tina O.

description:
Been here twice, the first time with friends and the second time with my boyfriend. I like looking around the shop at their toys and candy especially cus they're all Asian oriented! They're kinda expensive though so I don't buy the treats from there haha.

I just get the crepes! They're a good size and yummy. Nothing really to complain about. Pretty fast. Only complaint would be that there's a bench that's half-in the store and half-out the store, and a small table with two chairs outside to eat at. Otherwise, you can walk around the street with the other restaurants around to eat your crepe!
author: Samy L.

description:
Genki is my weakness in life. 

Whether it is their crepes or their selection of Asian snacks and drinks, I cannot avoid spending money here. 

You might want to share the crepe because they are pretty large. They are also pretty to-go friendly in their easy-carry paper holders. The last time I was there we got peanut butter, bananas, almonds, and vanilla ice cream. Yea, the bf likes to order anything and everything when I'm paying :] But it was a good, filling combo. I've also had nutella and various fruit combination. I've never been anything but happy with my crepes.

Other than the crepes, I tend to get their chocolate gummy candies. You can find them up front by the register in those cylinder canisters. Just don't get the M&M like ones on accident because I've done that more than once! We also like to get the aloe drinks from them. They also have a big selection of frozen snacks/ice cream treats like mochi and my favorite is the waffle cone w/ white chocolate chips w/ ice cream sandwich like thing. MMmmm, mmmm!
author: Danielle G.

description:
CREPES! CREPES! CREPES! I really like the crepes here. I usually always order a Nutella w/ Strawberries. Sometimes I get Nutella w/ Cheesecake & Strawberry Ice Cream & it's SOOO DELICIOUS! I only order that when I feel like going "all-out," haha. I love the crispy texture to it. Also, I like how you can hold it in one hand, which comes in handy when you're driving. They have tons of choices for crepes, both savory & sweet..I always get the sweet ones though. Tons of toppings. They have tapioca drinks, ice cream, egg puffs as well.  

Lots of asian snacks, candy, & drinks located here. You always can find something. My go-to's are Pocky & Hi-Chew Candy. 

The wait can get ridiculous. Sooo many people go to Genki Crepes..you're either waiting to order or waiting for your order. Hopefully you come at the beginning of the "rush." Or try going during non-peak hours..maybe you'll just get lucky. 

There's 2 small benches inside to wait &/or eat your order. There's also 2 tables outside. 

Parking is...non-existent, haha! Super hard to find parking for multiple reasons: it's Clement, lots of busy businesses around, people who were there first & are already circling around, & more. You really have to be lucky or go at a really odd hour/time. Late nights (especially Friday & Saturday) are the hardest. Good luck! 

CASH ONLY.
author: Jessica A.

description:
I was here the other night because it was the only thing that was open past 10pm.  A star just for staying open.  Heh, I guess in some places in San Francisco, 10pm is considered "late night."  

Anyway, I've been here a couple times, and their crepes are pretty decent.  I usually get crepes with fillings that I know they can't botch - like red bean.  I also like their eggettes, which are these hollowed out waffle-like things.  They're not super delicious, but they're pretty fun to eat while you're walking down Clement.  Just pop one in your mouth; it's fun.

Anyway, yeah, their crepes are decent, and come in a variety of savory or sweet flavors.  I usually go for the sweet flavors, and it's good with ice cream too.  They have some very strange savory flavors (Hot link + mozarella + onion = uh...what?) which I'm not exactly keen on trying, but maybe some brave soul out there will eat one of these weird combination crepes.

So, for post-meal dessert, Genki is pretty good, and it's always nice to walk up and down Clement, crepe in hand, friend by your side.  The store itself is also pretty cute and has all sorts of Japanese treats, sweets, and trinkets, but it's not exactly cheap.  You can usually get some of the same Pocky, Calpico drinks, etc. at nearby May-Wah, which has EVERYTHING you could ever want, at affordable prices.

Final word: Genki = Good for crepes.   Everything else in the store = Go to MayWah instead.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Careful, you might not make it to your original point of destination if you happen to pass by Genki Crepes. Your nose will steer you to this Richmond's finest snackery. They have shelves and shelves of Asian candy! It's better than County Square Market in Concord. They also have delicious egg puffs that go oh-so-well with a cup of joe next door. 

By smell alone, this place is A+!
author: Tatyana K.

description:
I love the Salmon Crepes here!!! So recommended...
Besides, this place is place junk-food mini-mart. Come here whenever i craving for candy/snack...This place has some foods that u can not find at common Chinese market.
Not really good place for milk tea..So i recommend u purchase crepes here and go to Quickly across the street- a better place for boba milk tea.
author: IVY D.

description:
Genki is one of my top 2 places for dessert crepes in SF. I like how there's a little mini-mart in the store to browse around while waiting for your order. Just keep in mind that some of those things may be over priced though.

I have always left satisfied when I visit Genki because they always make it just right, a little crispy so it's not soggy. A crepe by myself is usually really filling (it has become my dinner a few times now). But if you're not that hungry, you can always share with a friend :)

I'd visit this place more often, but its so out of the way. And sometimes parking may be harder to find on certain days.
author: Harriet W.

description: Line out the DOOR. They got other snacks that you might want be tempted to get but wait for it cause you wanna do some work on the crepe you're about to put down.
author: John B.

description:
Ohhh man so good. I (lovingly) call this place "Janky" Crepes, but janky it is not! They have an awesome selection of great Japanese goods, great mochi and mochi ice cream, ramune, candy, look chocolates, meiji almonds, lots of amazing stuff.

But the most important reason to come here is the crepes. My favourite is the Blueberry Cheesecake crepe, and it is so insanely awesome. I once got the Ice Cream Strawberry one by mistake (I think they gave me someone else's by mistake, oops) but it was also awesome. My other usual is nutella-banana.

Heads up though as they are not the usual kind of soft, French crepe. These are more crunchy, and are a bit different texture than you might expect. Amazing fillings though and a nice tasty dessert treat, big enough to share with someone.
author: Mike J.

description:
I love their ice cream crepes! I have never gotten one of their savory ones because I can't help myself, but to get one of those sweet ice cream and nutella filled ones :). They have crepes you can choose from on their menu or you can make your own. They have a few flavors of ice cream that I have never heard of before, so it's a new good taste. I typically get one of their ice creams depending on what I'm in the mood for and add nutella and some kind of fruit, like bananas or strawberries. It is so good!

It is cash only, unless you reach a certain total, then you could use your card.
I think the prices are decent for what you get because it is very tastey.

The place is small and can pack up pretty fast at night, but during the day is not as busy. There is no place to sit but outside. It can sometimes be cold eating your delicious crepe out there, but that's ok! It is a convenience store with lots of Asian snacks, drinks, and miscellanious things to buy, too.

Parking here can sometimes be difficult to find. I typically have to drive around for a while before getting lucky with a spot.
author: Monica M.

description:
This place is definitely delicious but it really depends on the kind of crepes that you like. Nothing about this place dessert wise (ice cream, fruit-filled crepes) was exceptionally good, but it was good. I think the distinguishing feature this place has, aside from its enormous crowd of people waiting to get crepes outside, is the fact that their crepes are very thin and crispy instead of soft and thick and they have great egg puff pastries. 

I think this is a fun little place and the Japanese market attached, although overpriced, has some neat trinkets that are definitely entertaining to check out. It is, however, CHEAP for a crepe as many other crepe places charge up to $6 for a standard crepe with ice cream and fruit.

I would definitely come back here again, but my preference is not for a super crispy crepe :)
author: Lorrie M.

description: Amazing crepes! I love their Nutella Banana Almond crepe. Their crepes have  more of a crunchy texture than what they usually are. Two thumbs up for this place.
author: Sam A.

description: Best Crepes everrrr!!! There always seems to be people waiting for crepes at all times during the day. I love the crunchy crepes with generous amounts of ice cream. The one thing I'd complain about is how stingy they are on strawberries! I only had three small chunks! Overall still delicious. My boyfriend is always talking about Genki when we're nearby. I heard their egg puffs are delicious as well, I'll give that a try the next time I come by =]
author: Thanh N.

description:
BEST CREPES ON EARTH!!...ok well that probably isn't true considering there are about a ga-zillion other crepe places, but these are definitely MY FAVORITE by far! They're simple, yet amazingly delicious. And they have the best asian ice cream flavors ever. Mmmm mango, lychee, and green tea!

FAVORITE COMBINATION: mango ice cream + strawberries  :)

* the mini Japanese market is cute as well*
author: Kristen C.

description:
Skipping dessert at a restaurant to go to a crepes place? Most definitely! I like walking around Clement anyway. 

The number of choices stunned me. How was I going to pick?! This could take half an hour...."my favorite is strawberry banana nutella." Alrighty then! Good thing we sped that decision along. 

It wasn't bad but for a few bucks, I wasn't expecting a whole lot either. The fruit was fresh, and everything is cooked to order, of course. Crispy isn't what I prefer in a crepe, though; it was somewhat similar to a sugary ice cream cone. Next time I'll try a savory crepe....

Since it's a mini-mart as well, there's no ambience. Stand or sit on a bench inside the double doorway.
author: Mike H.

description: Ok a with the 1700 or so others who think this place is a must stop, my vanilla Nutella crepe was amazing!  Even with the parking nightmare I'm giving this spot 5 stars! Delicious and fast even with a line out the door.  Do yourself a favor and drop by for a crepe and an egg puff.  I got the banana, yum!
author: Julie S.

description:
It's nice to have an Asian mini-mart/crepe shop that's open late night.
Came here last Saturday with a couple friends (my first time) and so far, I'm very pleased. Although there were hoards of people waiting in and out of the shop, I was able to place my order and receive my crepe in 10 or so minutes. I was sort of zoning out, but I managed to peek around the store. They have a wide array of drinks (including packs of ramuné, mmm), snacks, trinkets & toys and.... cosmetics! Unfortunately I was in a rush (well, not me.. but my friends) and had to leave after picking up the crepes, so I didn't get to browse as much as I wanted to.

Hopefully I'll be back here soon.. I really want to go explore what the rest of the store has to offer.
author: Sophia Q.

description:
Beyond the crepes, the mini mart is awesome! Unique Japanese KitKats (selection today included Royal Milk Tea, Marron, Dark Almond Chocolate, and Flan), special toys in boxes (the ones where you don't know which one you're going to get - toys include Hello Kitty, Rilakkuma, etc), drinks, and snacks (maple syrup flavored Cheetos, anyone?).

Spend $50 and you get a cool reusable bag.
author: Katherine P.

description:
BEST CREPE SPOT....EVER! 

I always order #16 with extra orange sauce!

It consists of hot links, red onions, and ooey gooey mozzarella cheese covered in their genius ORANGE SAUCE! Their orange sauce is just ketchup, Japanese mayo, and sriracha sauce. 
My boyfriend on the other hand likes their dessert crepes. Those are really good too, but i prefer a savory crepe. Mostly because it's hard to find a spot that makes savory crepes, let alone good ones!

oh, and their drink selection is amazing! Lilikoi Hawaiian Sun is my personal favorite. Try it, you will NOT leave disappointed!
author: Lily S.

description:
Out of every place I've tried egg puffs at in the Bay Area, this is by far my favorite.

I normally get the vanilla egg puff, but this past Saturday I decided to try the strawberry egg puff. It was pretty good but not as good as the vanilla one. I like that the egg puffs stays crispy for hours so I can eat it at my own pace without worrying about it getting soggy.

The crepes are pretty good, but not the best that I've had. My aunt knows how to make some tasty crepes, so I rather have her make me unlimited crepes than to waste $5 buying one. 

Along with yummy desserts, they offer a bunch of Japanese snacks in their store. 

Warning: Do not buy the Milk Tea. It's gross.
author: Olivia W.

description:
2 1/2 Stars. I went earlier this week and ordered a dessert crepe with Lychee ice cream and yogurt. not impressive at all. I would rather just travel down to Sophie's crepes. 

The crepe itself was so flaky and crispy, not the way a crepe is supposed to be. If I wanted that I'd get chips.

The yogurt was some plain white jello or something, not enough and you couldn't taste it. bad combo.

I've has the Green tea ice cream with actual lychee fruit in it. not a good combo as well. I only really eat here if I don't care, then I get reminded why I don't usually go there.

since the line does get kind of long my friend and i have called in advance and picked them up. At least then you don't have to wait in that line and you're out of there!
author: Leanne K.

description:
Who doesn't like Crepe?! "CRUNCH. MUNCH, MUNCH."The cold, sweet spheres of ice cream mixed with the warm, crunchy outside-absolutely scrumptious. ASDFGHJKL. Crepes instill feelings that linger even after the consumption. 
My Crepe philosophy: "Once you have crepe, you feel elated. Once the crepe becomes consumed, you buy more."
author: Steven V.

description: I used to get crepes here regularly. After several months of abstaining, I stopped in tonight for  a late night crepe. Usually there is a healthy queue, but not tonight. I noticed the prices have gone up. I ordered a caramel-custard-banana crepe for $4.95. I left a nice tip and got a a crumbly piece of dough with almost no custard and almost no caramel and a some really green bananas. I took 2 bites and asked for my money back. They wouldn't give me my money back and were pretty rude. I threw most of it in the trash. They raised the prices and lowered the quality. OK, for $6 I learned not to come back here.
author: John B.

description:
My first experience with Japanese Crepes - Viva La Froonch.

These are not the tender, almost chewy, thin pancake-like batter that you love your nutella and liqour nestled in. No, these are crunchy, delecate and brittle triangles of rather dry dough.

I chose a simple filling of bananas, honey and almonds and though I uttered not a complaint - I knew that right across the street was a French Creperie that I wished we were on the doorstep of instead. 

I'm a Little Piggy, so of course I got the coconut egg waffles too, these I liked on the same level, a little dry, a little tasteless - but fun in shape. Had they perhaps a coconut filling instead of essence, or maybe some whipped cream to help them, they may have shone a little more character.

As for next time, I'm going to French It.
author: Katie W.

description:
Genki Crepes looks like just a typical small market.  But what makes it stand it out, of course, are the freshly made crepes and snacks.  They serve ice-cream crepes (featuring red bean, lynchee, mango, green tea ice creams), savory crepes (like ham, cheese, salmon, wasabi), and my favorite, snack/dessert crepes (example: cheesecake, blueberry sauce).  

My boyfriend and I ordered the #21, nutella and banana crepe ($3.95) and the strawberry egg puffs ($3.25) to share.  Since we went around 2:00 p.m., there wasn't any wait.  We ordered our snacks and explored the shop while we waited, which was only about 5 minutes.  

The crepe was done first and it had a decent amount of both Nutella and bananas.  The bananas were thinly sliced and evenly distributed around the cone shaped crepe.  The crepe was made just right where it was crispy but not overly flakey.  You could take a bite of it without squishing all of the filling to one side, or having it fall out in a mess.

The strawberry egg puffs were pretty good, but didn't really seem like anything special.  They were crisp on the edges and easy to break apart, while being soft/chewy-ish on the "puff" part.  My boyfriend definitely liked the crepe better.

For those not in a crepe or egg puff mood, they also sell blended drinks for $2.50 and milk shakes for $3.95, featuring flavors like taro,  giner, papaya and sesame.  

Overall, I'd say Genki Crepes is about a 3.5, but I'll round up because they have such a wide variety of offerings. 

Notes:
-There is metered street parking right in front, or go around the corner for free 2-hour parking and use the change you saved to buy some Asian candy inside.
-They have a few benches for you to sit and enjoy your crepes.
author: Samantha L.

description:
G reat Dessert Crepes
E asily the best in the Richmond district
N utella -- enjoy it in your crepe, then buy a jar of it there
K iwi, strawberry and ice cream make nice fillings, too
I f you want just the crepe batter, get the Egg Puffs
author: Anthony N.

description:
2 stars solely on the crepes. I've been here twice and each time my crepes come out looking realllyy really good. However, looking good and tasting good are completely different. The crepes aren't warm or chewy like how they're supposed to be. Instead, they are rock hard and hurt my teeth to bite into. Although the crepes are big, I'd rather have the quality be better. The strawberries and bananas aren't sweet enough either. The only good thing about the crepes are the ice cream(they have mango, cantaloupe, green tea, red bean, and a whole bunch of flavors you don't normally get).

4 stars for the service. The staff were HILARIOUS. We came in two nights in a row and one of the guys remembered us. They were really really nice especially since both nights we came in at 12:25 near closing time and the first night we staggered in drunk.

All in all, Sophie's is better but I'd come back for the ice cream and their little asian market.
author: Tina T.

description:
O genki desuka? 

Genki des...

After eating at China First restaurant, we headed just a few steps away towards Genki Crepes for desserts. As I mentioned on my previous review, we discovered this place while checking out the neighborhood. Hmmmm, another long line but we didn't mind since we were full and blissfully wallowing on the few pounds that we gained. 

First thing I noticed was the smell of crepes permeating in the area. It's a nice aroma and someone should bottle it and sell it as a perfume. This ought to attract some attractive people. Just like the Axe commercial; just spray some on you and watch the ladies go crazy. OK...enough of my delusions of grandeur. 

My youngest son and I both ordered the Vanilla Ice Cream, Bananas with Whipped Cream. My oldest ordered the Chocolate Ice Cream and Cheesecake with Whipped Cream. The wifey ordered Vanilla Ice Cream, Strawberries, Nutella with Whipped Cream. I also ordered a Cantaloupe Milkshake for the road.  

While waiting for your order, you can look around the store. This place also doubles as a mini mart and they sell Japanese knick knack toys to different kinds of Pocky, the Japanese Snack Food. OK, it's junk food but I happen to like them. Of course we couldn't resist on stocking up our pantry. What started as a dessert trip ended up being a shopping spree. 

We finally got our order and couldn't wait to chow them down. The Vanilla Ice Cream was good as it had a nice sweetness and texture. It definitely wasn't your plain ole vanilla like the ones at your local Safeway store. The Whipped Cream was creamy and delish. I just wished they had more slices of bananas in there. Of course I also sampled my wifey's and son's for comparison. I should've gotten the Nutella as well.

Overall, it was good...but not as good as Sophie's Crepe in Japantown. Even though the crepe was thick and crispy, it was a tad on the salty side for my taste. I would normally finish the whole thing but I couldn't get past the saltiness of the crepe. Don't worry, it didn't go in the garbage. I gave the rest to Maxie. Maxie is our resident garbage disposal and doubles as a vacuum cleaner.

Maxie was just too happy to oblige. She said Domo Arrigattuo.
author: John G.

description:
It's hard to roll through Clement without stopping at Genki.  It's like those crepes are magnetically charged and you find yourself gravitating towards that giant orange Genki sign when you really never intended to.

No amount of fullness can deter you from coming here.  Shit, not even being lactose intolerant can keep my buddy from getting a double scoop of their mango ice cream.  

My lactose friend's request: extra star for having non-poopy ice cream.  Apparently her giant double scoop of ice cream didn't cause explosive diarrhea so I guess this is now a 6-star review.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Genki crepes was simply amazing.  Really satisfying.  Make sure to make a trip here when you're in the city.  You won't be disappointed.  I got the Nutella and marshmallow crepe and it was so well done and fresh.  They also have bubble tea/smoothies.  
$4 for a crepe on average. Not too bad at all. Really cheap. They have dessert crepes, savory crepes, and also ice cream crepes.  Honestly enough to satisfy any type of craving you may be having.  They accept cards only above $10.
author: Neel I.

description:
THIS IS A BIG CANDY SHOP !!! 

Despite all the snacks, candies, things that give you cavities, their crepes stand out. I've only had their sweet crepes but never had their savoury ones (ham, cheese, etcetc.)

I think my favorite crepe from them is their green tea and lychee crepe. Scoops of green tea ice cream wrapped in a freshly cooked thin crepe. But, the only downside of this is the amount of lychees they give you! I think they place 2 or 3 on top, and throughout the whole crepe, you don't get any lychees til the very end. They place one on the tip of the crepe. SAD! This goes the same for all their ice cream and fruit crepes. Same with their mango ice cream and strawberry crepe. Sad! 

Parking here is hard on a daily basis and everytime I come to Genki, there's at least 10 people in front of me. Now that we're going through economic troubles, I'm not sure if the line is still just as long. I would wait in line for their crepes unless it was raining out, then it's not worth it, haha. 

Overall, good sweet crepes. I have to come back here to try their savoury ones.
author: Heidi C.

description: This place was awesome. I had a nutella and marshmallow crepe and it was delicious. I also tried the vanilla egg puffs which tasted like a vanilla fortune cookie crossed with a waffle. Thai tea with boba was on the money as well, and this place was an awesome asian market. Tons of cool drinks and snacks to take to go.
author: Michael R.

description: Delicious crepes and a mini mart! I always end up getting a crepe with strawberries, nutella, vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. The crepes always taste amazing here and the service has been pretty fast every time I came to visit. Plus, you can browse around the mini mart while you wait for your order. I always end up getting candy too while I wait for my crepe to be ready.
author: Beca P.

description: I didn't even order a crepe, but Joe and I purchased a box of Hello Pandas, those amazing cookies -- especially the ones with the chocolate filling yummmm.  We were walking on Clement St, and I was immediately drawn in by the amazing assortment of treats in their aisles.  Some of my favorite candies and cookies were in there, and I easily could have spent an hour checking everything out!
author: Mel G.

description: Wonderful flavors and toppings! Didn't expect this to be in a mini-mart but I still enjoy the wonderful crepes the make. My favorite is the red bean paste with green tea ice cream which has some fruit in it. Fresh and fast! I just wish that the workers there had a little more enthusiastic. There was a girl/lady working there with a cap on and she seemed as if she didn't care about her job. Needs improvement on their friendliness in the environment of the "cafe".
author: Sarah F.

description: the bad thing is that it's always crowded, but man, is it good. a lot of choices for whatever urge you may have, but the dessert choices are where it's at. the fact that it is a convenient store/market definitely threw me off at first; they should just convert the entire storefront into an eatery, and it'd still have no problem filling up the place. parking, of course, is a pain, so if you think you can endure that and the large crowd, then totally go for it.
author: Mike C.

description:
I'm sorry this place kills Sophie's crepes in jtown =o(IMO you don't have to agree with me but I've eaten at both places a lot). After king of thai bf always takes me here to grab Japanese snacks and a yummy dessert crepe. My all time fav has to be vanilla ice cream, strawberry & nutella. Ohmygahhh I want one right now! The crepe is thin and delicious-you can't go wrong here!! There's always a long line here but you barely have to wait 10 minutes to get your crepes...score!
my only grr moment is that the strawberries are frozen and then thawed out, so sometimes i can taste the freezer burn :(
author: Tammy M.

description:
Long before my Yelping days I'd go into Genki and totally ignore the crepes and other good things they made in the front of the market just to stock up on some of my favorite Japanese candies and occasionally try something different in Japanese snacks and beverages.

Then my Yelping days came along, and everybody raved about the crepes.  I'll be honest.  I never really noticed.  I had to try it once though, and I finally did so just a few weeks ago.  Now I've tried them three times already.  The savory one with ham, cheese and lettuce was not too bad, but the sweet ones with vanilla ice cream and fresh fruit has got me hooked.

They're great for a middle-of-the-day snack or an after-dinner treat, but considering that this place gets kind of crowded at night I'll stick to making these a mid-day treat.  Now when I drop in for a couple bags of candy you can be sure that I'll stick around for a crepe.  I've never had Nutella though, nor have I had those egg puff thingies.  Maybe I'll try them next.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
When I first went here (trying to kill some time while waiting for Burma Superstar), I wasn't that impressed - I could make a crepe and scoop green tea ice cream and smear a little red bean, what's the big deal?

But I find myself thinking about that lovely crepe and I try to go whenever I'm in the neighborhood. They craft their crepes so that I don't have to, and they do a bang-up job at it!
author: christine l.

description:
The crepes were fine but the cashier was EXTREMELY rude. We couldn't understand what she said and gave us attitude when we misunderstood what she said. Makes me feel old to say that the girl needed to annunciate better.
As we were not rude I was offended by the service and plan to go elsewhere. 
In hindsight I wish we would have leftwithout finishing our order.
I don't plan to return although I was a repeat customer already.
author: Miharu Y.

description:
Crepes ? 5 Stars
Prices ? 5 Stars
Staffs ? 1 - 5 Stars...

So I'm a regular for this place and I usually only order crepes, either Nutella+Butter+Almonds OR Ham+Cheese+Mayo+Ketchup, I usually be there around 7-8 p.m. and this past Sunday I was there around 9pm and see a new girl I never met before at the register, no biggie since that wouldnt make any thing different right ? WRONG ! so I tell her I'd like to have my regular Ham+Cheese+Mayo and Ketchup, she replied... "We have no Ketchup." ... I was stunned, the ketchup is right behind her where they keep their sauces(chili sauce, mayo etc.) for the crepes, I wasn't ready for her answer so I was thinking to myself... "maybe the ketchup is expired.." so I told her nevermind and decided not to order anything, I kept thinking to myself though and wonder why would they keep it there if it's expired so I walk up to her again and order the same thing but tell her "the ketchup is right there *points finger* I usually order it here" she replies "I don't know how to write it down and how much I should charge" ... alright, I was super pissed by then but being a cool, calm and collected guy I am.I decided not to say anything to her and tell her "I'll just have no.11 without lettuce (which is Ham+Cheese+Mayo+Lettuce)" she nods then I get my crepe...

The whole time I was thinking "why is she so dumb (sorry but it's true) since she could just SWITCH the lettuce that I didn't need to ketchup ? OR, just charge me whatever she charges orders with extra sauce or whatever ? I mean like, what the hell ? I was super pissed but then again I feel so terrible being mad just because I didn't get the crepe how I wanted it.

But seriously...
author: SuShiLoveR I.

description:
So Lubs was talking about how great these egg puffs were, so I had to go check them out. Disappointing! I got the honeydew flavored ones, and I think I gave away half of mine, and dropped a few puffs here and there for the homeless. I tried a bite of one of their crepes, I think the swiss cheese. It was very gross.

The store is kind of laid out like a Japanese convenience store/supermarket  with the usual Japanese snacks and capsule toys. The snacks here are very expensive, about a 50% markup from Mitsuwa or Niyjia market, so save your money for a snack run.
author: Grace Y.

description:
The first time I was here I ordered their eggettes. They were no good; each eggette snapped off in the paper bag as I walked out to my car, and were kinda hard- almost like a hush puppy. Quality much?

The second time I was here was a Friday night. This place was PACKED. I ordered the Nutella and marshmallow crepe. The filling was good but the crepe itself was rubbery. I felt like a savage, needing to rip off a chunk to eat by holding the crepe with both hands and ripping it away from my face.

They have a nice selection of JDM snacks and souvenirs you can browse through too. Its a nice touch and a good place for people who are bored or high school hooligans to hang out in, but its not the place if you're looking for a good crepe to satisfy a crepe craving.
author: Felix C.

description:
It is good, but I'm not a sweets type person. But several friends love this place. I have to admit the crepe part is good! Lots of random stuffing to pick from...Sweets, meat, etc.

Yummmmmm
author: Shine S.

description:
Possibly my favorite spot in SF.

EVERYTHING is good here. I won't go into detail on the food, because all of the other positive reviews are true. And I will start salivating if I start talking about their crepes.

Genki's is an extremely fun atmosphere. I always go here with groups of friends...the late hours are soooooo convenient. Amazing place to go to, especially when nothing else is still opened. I love just walking down the aisles looking for new things to try. Oh, and I swear this is like the only Asian place in SF that accepts card!

Seriously, if you haven't tried Genki, GOOO!
author: Kayla I.

description:
It's simple! Genkis is amazing! The actual crepe is so crunchy and there are tons of combinations! (Though I've never tried anything other than the nutella with banana and vanilla ice cream) 

The location is awesome with the mini Japanese market and all of the Asian candy and knick knacks!

I am a believer in Genkis! :)
author: Empee P.

description: Very nice crepes - try the one with mango ice cream. Real nice. They make the crepe crispy too so the ice cream doesn't make it soggy. Look forward to going back there again!
author: Anwar H.

description: Their crepe skin (is that what you call it..?) is OK. I got their lychee crepe with green tea ice cream. The ice cream is yummy but I seriously only got two pieces of lychee in there (mind you, each of those pieces was barely half a lychee..). I like that it's the crispy crepes but I won't be craving this place anytime soon.
author: Jolene L.

description:
Dude, no.  it's crowded, and unorderly.  Nowhere to really enjoy it (if it tasted good).  Bleh.

I got the nutella with almonds.  The crepe itself was bitter.  It wsn't the nutella making it bitter.  But it tasted kinda burnt... though it wasn't.  It was a nice golden brown and it really looked good.  But bleh.  I forced myself to finish it as I don't like to waste food.

The Thia tea sucked too.  I really, REALLY don't get the hype.
author: Darren T.

description:
Cammy was raving about the crepes here so we decided to drop by after an evening of good food and debauchery (thanks to Euge's event). 

We shared a strawberry/whipped cream/nutella crepe.  Crepe was HUGE and crispy on the outside and I'm glad they didn't stuff the crepe so much you couldn't take a bite without getting bits of whipped cream all over your mouth.   I really enjoyed the crepe here and will have to go and get a nutella/banana combo one day.
author: Nette T.

description:
I always went to Genki Crepes for their ...*drumroll* ... CREPES! They have a lot of Asian flavored ice cream so it appeals to my tastes.

My favorite order? Nutella spread with lychee ice cream; sometimes I would top that off with fresh fruits as well. My boyfriend shared one with me once and, although he isn't a fan of sweets, he consumed it.

I had a bite of my friend's red bean spread with green tea ice cream and it tasted delicious! If you're bored of eating sweet crepes the French way (i.e. strawberries and whipped cream) go to Genki's and try the crepes with an Asian twist. I assure you, you will not be disappointed.
author: Evonne M.

description: Perfect pit stop for Japanese goodies and crepes! The shop is connected to a little Japanese market that's sells all kinds of snacks that are imported from Japan. As for my crepe order... Green tea ice cream, red beans, and chocolate please!
author: Janice K.

description:
It satisfies my sweet tooth late at night. Why?
First of all, Clement street is a war zone during the day. 
Don't attempt to drive here in the daylight, you have to fight through the millions of bad Chinese drivers. 
Later at night however, is a different story. It's calmed down quite a bit and usually all you hear is belligerent drunkards smoking outside The Bitter End or Rock It Room, or the other bars.. 

Genki's is my late night Clement haven. Not only can I get a strawberry and whipped cream crepe, I can get the Meiji Choco gummies!! You know, the chocolate covered gummies that come in a tube. OH MAN I LOVE THOSE THINGS 
I am so addicted to them. I want to drive there right now and buy some but it's 11:30 and they're closed. =(

It's Asian snacks and beverage heaven!!!
author: Susy C.

description:
YUMMMMMM. I love getting crepes from here. I've been here roughly over 10 times. I always get some sort of ice cream crepe, which costs around $5. And that's $5 well spent! Sometimes the ice cream leaks out the bottom, which is super messy, but I guess if you eat quickly enough, it isn't much of an issue. The one time I tried a savory crepe, the spinach and mushroom one, I was sort of disappointed. Nothing was wrong with it per say, but I just wasn't wowed and felt like I had to order it again. The place gets crowded on the weekends, but the line moves quickly. This place is perfect for a warm day, hell, any day.

Overall, stick to the sweet crepes and you'll be satisfied!
author: Christina S.

description: Odd crepe place in the front of a mini-mart. However the crepes are really good. I had the green tea crepe with red bean paste. The price was right. Limited seating and parking.
author: Cheryl L.

description: Ohhh man.. I've been craving crepes from here for about half a year now ever since I saw people walking out with their huge crepes. I finally got to coming back and experience it for myself. I got the strawberry crepe with mango ice cream. It was like holding a huge ice cream cone! The crepe itself was pretty crispy but not fortune cookie status. But the best part was the mango ice cream!! As artificial as it looked, it was pretty amazing and tasted almost like real mangos! Pair it with the crepe and you'll want another one! They did skimp out on the strawberries though. I seriously could not find them for the life of me. Only a couple of sliced pieces on the top and bottom. Overall, it is a good treat once in a while and I'll make sure to try the savory ones next time!
author: Stella Y.

description:
When I'm on Clement, I have to make a stop at Genki.  Everytime i Walk in here, I automatically smile and get very excited.  They have amazing crepes,  a great variety Asian candies and goodies and a ton of Hi-Chew flavors (I am a Hi-Chew addict, I call then super Mambas).  I haven't ordered a crepe here in awhile but Nutella and banana is my ultimate favorite.  The crepe is so thin and crispy and the ratio of Nutella to bananas is perfect.  I have had crepes in France and I prefer crepes here. Another great thing about Genki is that they stay open really late (I am sort of a nightcrawler).  

If you haven't been to Genki yet you need to.  Order a crepe and pick up some Hi-Chew :)
author: danielle l.

description:
Came here after dinner at Q.  The boyfriend wanted a crepe with chocolate cake and ice cream.  Really?  Ok....well, turns out it was still pretty tasty.  Not as tasty as a nutella crepe with strawberries and ice cream, but whatever....they have that option if you decide to go with that one instead.

They also have tasty snacks and deliciousness that you can buy...like every burger or those gummy fruit snacks that you know you love.

Next time we're going here I'm going to get a crepe with nutella, strawberries and ice cream...cause everyone knows that's far superior to one with chocolate cake (although, admittedly, it was pretty tasty still...just don't let the boyfriend know I admitted to that!)
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Wow Genki crepes is pretty darn tasty.  I love how it's extra crispy "skin" compliments the toppings.  Since we just had Shabu Shabu I decided to skip the ice cream.  I had the strawberries, nutella and whipped cream and it was super tasty.

Nom nom nom!

I love how the store is like a convenient store as well.  All the good eats that you can enjoy and Japanese snacks and hairdye to boot.

I would have loved to see our friend eat the Cheesecake crepe but he was feeling too full.  Heard you can pass out for the decadence of it all.
author: Christine K.

description:
I wish I lived closer to eat these crepes EVERY day. I'm serious, I took my friend here and we ordered our owns AND shared another one. We INHALED both crepes in 15 minutes. ALSO, while eating outside, a family walks by and their child stops and look at us gorging our faces with these beautiful made huge crepes. It was the cutest thing ever. He made that night so much better, we didn't know to feed him or just let him stare at us. 

Get the number 18, chicken, cheddar, sweet & sour sauce and YUMM! or the number 17 with beef sukiyaki. The ham and pineapple one is great too! 

ALL of their dessert options for crepes is to die for. For under $6, WHY go anywhere else! 

Note* they have a $10 minimum for credit cards, but its located in a little asian convience store, look around, I swear you'll wanna buy everything. :) They have nice imported car freshners and asian goodies(candies that...have asian writing... :) )
author: Amy Q.

description:
this place is ok, nothing special about this place. it's good but they put waaay too much in the crape so one crape would be good for 2 people. 
I come here once in a while when i'm craving.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
First of all I would like to thank a very dear friend of mine for taking me to Genki--FOR THE FIRST TIME!! (Yeah, I'm 21, a native of SF, never really did much exploring until I attended college--mom always wanted me home and didn't want me spending so much money)

I'm the type of person that likes to be different and try new things. On Yelp I saw that the strawberry + nutella crepe was a big hit but already having a huge jar of nutella at my apartment didn't cause me to crave it so bad. 

Being here for the first time, the crepe that popped my Genki cherry was...WAIT FOR IT...#7. The Chocolate Ice Cream + Cheesecake crepe. NOMZ! Filled me up like a meal. If it wasn't for the Thai Ice Tea (thanks grand big!) at King of Thai a couple doors down (stomach was filled with liquid), I would've enjoyed it more and wouldnt've felt like such a fatty. Got crumbs all over myself and the floor--that's how yummy it was.

5 stars--I'll come here again. Save me a seat on one of those benches please!
author: Amanda S.

description: The only place I go for crepes.  Service was great everything was done quick and affordable, not to mention delicious . Would definitely recommend to a friend
author: Melissa D.

description:
I was disappointed today when I got my crepe here.  Because of the high ratings and not to mention the number of people who rated this place, I think I came in with high expectations.  I ordered the ice cream banana and mango crepe.  The crepe came out looking like a waffle cone; very crispy.  It was thick too.  The toppings were pretty much separated; ice cream at the bottom, topped with banana, mango, and whip cream.  Of course, I had trouble with melted ice cream because it's hard to dig underneath the toppings.  

The price is fair. Not too generous with the fruit.  Would I go back? Probably not, unless I want a crispy crepe..... And crispy crepes are just not my thing.  So if you like crispy thick crepes, then this is the spot for you.
author: Kay L.

description:
I only tried the dessert crepes. It wrap is pretty darn crispy, so if you like it more of the crispy side then this is the place that knows how to fulfill your crepe urges and desires.. The crispiness is one of the most I tried it, and it started breaking off, compared to your soggy mushy of crepes..

I tried the strawberry w/nutella and vanilla ice cream. It is good. Anything is good with nutella along with a melting ice cream in a crepe.
author: kent c.

description:
Great dessert place to go after a delicious meal at Burma Superstar. Prolly some of the best crepes I've ever had. I loveeee Japanese crepes because they are crispy but chewy at the same time... and that is how they are supposed to be!! I really don't like crepes that are too soft and mushy. Idk how they do it, but their crepes are perfectly crispy throughout... even the last bite has a good crunch. I always share, but then regret it after. My recommendation is ice cream with nutella and banana. 

My only reservation to this place is that they don't really give you very much fruit and they cut their banana slices too large.
author: Alisa C.

description:
*:::Jenni LOVEs Genki Crepes:::*
Just can't get enough of genki crepes!
My favorite - Nutella with marshmallow ... Ummm! It's just like s'more but better! and blueberry cheesecake ;) it melts in your mouth!
author: Jenni C.

description:
Another one of my favorite go-to spots in the city!  It's an interesting little place where you can get crepes, japanese candy and snacks, drinks, toiletries, and even condoms LOL.  They've got a good selection of crepes (ice cream crepes, dessert crepes, and savory crepes), including egg puffs, boba drinks, shakes, teas, hot and cold drinks.  I love that they get their ingredients locally; they get their ice cream from Mitchell's (if you're familiar with Mitchell's, you know it's good!)
I wanted an ice cream crepe so bad, but because I'm lactose (sorry TMI) and I was not planning on heading home any time soon, I had to play it safe and selected a dessert crepe.  That night, I decided on the banana caramel custard crepe...mmm mmm good!  I'm sure you can imagine what that would taste like.  What I love about their crepe (wrap) is that it's made to perfection!  They serve it to you fresh, warm, and has got a slight crunch to it, not soggy.  Props to the crepe maker!  I've watched him make the crepes through the front window, and it's all in the technique.  =P
Next time, I will definitely get an ice cream crepe!  I just have to remember the to bring lactaid pills or keep a stash in my purse so I can be safe every time. =)
author: Sarah May O.

description:
For the guy screaming outside the store after the Giants game ended... this place is called "GHEN-KI" crepes, not "JANKY" crepes. Because I would wanna eat these crepes now after hearing you say that they're JANKY. 

Good thing I got my crepe before he got there because I don't want any "janky" crepes... 

Green Tea Ice Cream with Red Bean Spread and Whipped Cream Crepe (#2). YUM!!! I've missed you yummy crepe! This hit the spot after Crepe House Uni in Davis went out of business because they had something similar but with mochi in it. So this definitely hit the spot since I haven't had anything like it in months! LOVES! Green tea and red bean flavors work super well together and those flavors wrapped up in a crepe, even better! I gotta go back for more soon!
author: Constance C.

description:
I ordered the mixed fruit crepe with nutella.

I thought it was just ok.

May be if I didn't have the BEST crepe place in SoCal (Genki Living), I'd have rated this higher.

BUT, the fortunate thing is that I do and these dessert crepes just don't measure up.

I thought the flavor of the crepe was missing something, though it was well made in terms of it's thinness and crispiness.  The nutella and fruit mix was okay, but I really prefer the fruit, custard, and green tea combo I can get at Genki Living.

The Honeydew with Boba was actually pretty good, though the boba wasn't the best.
author: Bob C.

description:
i don't like dessert, with all honesty, for the most part, i loath sweets. then my friend took me to genki crepes and i gained 5 pounds =). if you go you have to order number 24. this crepe includes your choice of nutella or whip cream with fresh strawberries. by my forth or fifth crepe, while a spent a week in san francisco, i decided that having to choose between nutella and whip cream was not a fair choice, so for 50 cents more i decided to get both. getting both the nutella and cream was nothing short of magical. i honestly inhaled my very large crepe within a minute. i wish i could write about another item on the menu but why mess with a good thing? number 24 is the only thing i ate and if i go back i will continue to only get the number 24. yea..... it's that good =).

i wish you didn't have to spend 10 bucks to use a card, usually i would dock a star for not being consumer-friendly but the crepes are that good that it's still going to get a 5-star rating from me.
author: Michael G.

description:
For me, the Inner Richmond is the best neighborhood in SF to visit to satisfy my capricious whims and quixotic indulgences.

Forget the haute couture of Union Square, the ice creameries of the Mission, and the impeccably pecked men of the Castro. The Inner Richmond can soothe all of my cravings.

From the books at Green Apple, the bulgogi at Brothers, a trip to the therapist, a coffee at Blue Danube, a day is almost complete.

That's where almost comes in. It's not complete until you gratify the sweet tooth with a crepe at Genki's. They keep it simple and sweet; get the mixed fruit with nutella, with its batter crisped to perfection, and round out your day. If you're still a child at heart or in soul, there's a small selection of toys and trinkets to enjoy.

Genki will take you back to the Eden of your childhood, when calories were just a concept and toys were your life's totality.
author: Joanna M.

description: Super fast service and I really want to go back and try all the crepes and egg waffle things! YUMMM!!! It's half grocery store, half restaurant with little seating but you might as well take a walk with your crepe since they are served street food style in a paper cone.
author: Dana M.

description:
Meh. Yet another creperie that believes crispy crepes are better.

THEY. ARE. NOT. SUPPOSED. TO. BE. CRISPY.

Come on, now, people. I suppose it would be pretentious for me to tell people to "simply visit any crepe stand on the streets of Paris for a REAL crepe, even in the touristy areas." However, that may be EXACTLY what people need to get an idea of what a properly-cooked crepe should feel like.

Oh, and is it so hard to put a decent amount of butter on the thing?
author: Cody K.

description:
I've been here plenty of times during college days and recently revisited..it brings back a lot of good memories. 

Their crepes are hands down the best because the shell is actually crunchy and not soggy so it holds everything within.  The dessert crepes are enough to share between two people, especially if you get ice cream with it.  We regretted not getting nutella so definitely add it.  Only complaint is they are kinda stingy with the fruits in their dessert crepes.

I like how this place and the order of how they do things have not changed through the years...it makes coming back here enjoyable.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This place is always busy!! I ordered the Lychee & Custard crepe. It was OK. I'd say 6/10. My fault though, I decided to order something different instead of my usual nutella + fruit + vanilla. The custard isn't really solid custard like I thought it'd be, it was just custard drizzle. 

The wait is not too bad, they kind of rush you to order but what do you expect, it's super busy there. 

This place is also a little asian snack mini mart. 

The street also has other restaurants and bars. A lot of people seem to stop by in between drinks at Rockit room.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Crepes = delicious and crispy and warm.

Filling = savory or sweet, your choice.  I prefer the lychee ice cream with fruit and some whipped cream.  Other times, I stick with nutella and whipped cream.  :-)

Service = friendly.  

This place is kind of like a Japanese convenience store though...while you wait for the crepes...you can browse through their selection of Japanese food, drinks, toys and household necessities.  

Not much of seating indoors, so go sit outside, or walk around Clement with your food.  :-)  Or ask for a take-out box...
author: Fannie S.

description:
Happy Crepes! 

I love Genki! I wish I were closer, but it's probably good for my belly that I'm not. Ask for yours crispy and it's so much better. Crepes are perfect, thin, the staff is always nice. 

Need little Japanese treats, candy, snacks, gum, drinks, food, cooking ingredients, supplies, shampoo? They have a Japanese mini market with the crepe shop. I wish I could buy them out every time I go there.

Oh Genki, thank you for being there for me always.

Parking isn't great, but in that side of town it's never great. Just park a few blocks down and walk. You can work off the Genki on the way back. I also recommend coffee after wards from Blue Danube Coffee House, unless you prefer to get your drink on which they have those as well.
author: Lorrie N.

description: This is a place I always go to when visiting SF. The quality of the creeps seems to be a little bit lacking since the last time I was here. My crepe was way too crispy. My friend ordered his 'soft' so that's something to keep in mind next time. The selection is great and the price is pretty good.
author: Gina J.

description:
So it's pretty late (not hella late) and you've got a craving for some crepes. Where do you go?
None other than Genki on Clement! You can get your savory crepes such as chicken, pesto, mushroom or your sweet crepes like my favorite banana nutella. Hella good!
I also geek out with all the Japanese candies, chips, snacks, sodas, toys and other obscure things. 

If you haven't yet, Go to Genki, go check it out!
author: Ivan F.

description: One of my fave crepe places. The crepe is yummy in flavor and the filling is just right with nutella and strawberry and to top it off with chocolate ice cream and they make it like a giant cone. This is good for on the good esp walking around clement. I always have to stop by and grab a crepe when i'm in the area, no matter how full i am. This place is also reasonably priced, $7-8 for a crepe with ice cream.
author: Jamie M.

description:
You've gotta love the crepes here, they just have a different style to them. You can totally personalize them and concoct up something crazy from the variety of toppings; I usually go for something with ice cream, strawberries and nutella, or mangoes, strawberries and whipped cream. I'll agree, the crepe comes out a little thick, but that's essential when keeping its shape and form once loading in all the hot and cold fillings. You can safely eat an entire crepe without the entire thing turning soggy or leaky. Think of the science, chemistry and the physics of the crepe, people! Genki has got it down to an art.

The market is full of trinkets, stuffed toys, figurines, key chains, stationary, backpacks, dish towels all with familiar and maybe not so familiar cartoon and anime characters; many Sanrio characters, Sailor Moon, Totoro, Puka, Mashimaro, Doremon, Pokemon, etc. If you're a collector, this place could be dangerous. You'll also find pantry items like instant ramen, noodles, crackers, sauces, candy, cookies, a huge refrigerated section full of sodas, yogurt and fruit nectar drinks, teas, ice cream, mochi and other chilled sweets. They even have HELLO KITTY shaped nori flakes -- incredible! Shortly after I found a chocolate and crisped rice candy bar called CRUNKY, which pretty much describes me in a nutshell.

So, if you're too stuffed from Burma Superstar and can't possibly fit in dessert there, take a stroll down bustling Clement St. 'til your extra dessert stomach and nose lead you to Genki.

LOVED IT.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
Every time I go to Genki, I always get #27 with chocolate cake, whipped cream.. The chocolate cake always tasted fresh whenever I get some.  This place can get packed and there are only 2 benches to sit on.  I love how they are inside a market because it's where you'll find unique Asian treats.

The only problem you might have is finding a parking spot, considering how this place is located around an area with tons of food places.
author: Dee S.

description:
THE place to go when craving an ice cream crepe. It's a cool little store with a ton of unique Asian snack foods and drinks, but they're well known for their ice cream and savory crepes they create. They're open until 12:30am on Fri & Sat and there will always be a crowd of people outside sitting on the benches .

The Vanilla crepe with Nutella and whip cream is all I've ever had from this place and I've never been disappointed. Great place to go for dessert after eating in one of the MANY asian restaurants on the street (which is another plus for Genki..the location). 

Good for tasty dessert and to pick up some snacks, but if you're starving...come here after eating at a restaurant. They accept credit/debit cards.
author: Arnold N.

description: This place is rather pretty good.  Their egg puffs are so much better than many places I've tried.  Their ice-cream crepes are pretty tasty as well.
author: MB V.

description:
The crepes have gone downhill. They have super crispy edges and they are like thin paper with very little softness. They need to bring back the meticulous crepe-makers they had before as well as improve the recipe and/or process. Unfortunately, I won't be having a crepe here again. It's too bad because they've added some nice benches for seating.

There are some other tasty Japanese products here but I'd rather go to Nijiya for a wider selection.
author: Marina N.

description: Yummy crepes and eggpuffs.  The crepes are not as great as sophie's but a close and great alternative especially since they open pretty late!  You do have to wait awhile sometimes but it's a great little mini market that you can buy all different types of japanese goodies and drinks.  They often carry japanese kit kats here too :)
author: Kymberli C.

description:
Best place for sweet after dinner!!

 Good price for everything, many anime toy which to me is cool!!! But it is not cheap for the toy.

Nice people and friendly people, always lot of people at night but you don't have to wait long to get your order. 

Overall my favorite place for sweet!!
author: Calvin T.

description: I've been here a few times, but never thought to review until now. I haven't had a sweet crepe but their savory crepes are really yummy, and their mini market with assorted asian treats is just as awesome!! The crepes really fill you up for $5-6
author: Samantha D.

description:
Stopped by after dinner on Friday at Kappou Gomi.

Waited in line for a good 5 minutes.

Ordered 1 chocolate ice cream & cheesecake crepe, 1 egg puff, and 1 regular avocado shake with tapioca. (Total $14.21)

Egg puffs = sooooo good! far better than the ones at Quickly because these are crispy on the outside and airy in the middle.

Crepe = sooooo good x 2! I've never had crispy crepes before but they. are. delicious. it's like having thin waffle cones that are just soft enough so they don't cut up your mouth and melt as soon as you take a bite.

Avocado shake = I could not taste any avocado no matter how hard I tried. this is basically a vanilla milkshake with green coloring. the tapioca balls were perfectly cooked though.

I'm taking off a star because of the disappointing avocado shake and because the store has nowhere for people to stand in line and nowhere to sit afterwards. It's just a huge mess of people in the front of the store and standing outside while eating an ice cream crepe or milkshake really isn't pleasant (especially when it's so cold and windy...and this is Summer!).
author: Amaryllia L.

description:
For crepes, Genki's mediocre.  I kind of feel like all these Asian food fads come and go so fast, maybe this one (crepes)'s on its' last legs and not so innovative anymore.  

For stocking up on Asian snacks and competitive price point, I give Genki 3 stars.  Just down the street at a Vietnamese grocery store, I found my favorite crunchy seaweed snacks to be 30-cents more...  But maybe I should've just bought from down the street anyway, because the cashier at Genki had to punch in my debit/credit purchase, and somehow $11.61 turned into $116, and this actually put my bank account into a tizzy just before payday.

BOO on you!  (That should actually be NO STARS, but I understand sometimes stuff happens.  Unfortunately, it happened to MY bank account.)
author: Audrey E.

description:
Yum and it's not that expensive but why is it so far away from anything?!

B -- S
-- Good luck with parking, pal (after 6pm park at a meter)
-- Cash or $10 min credit card purchase
-- $3 - $5 for a dessert crepe
-- Ice cream & drinks available
-- Also a convenience store
-- A lot of cool stuff to buy
-- Gets busy in waves

My GF had been telling me about Genki. On our way back from the golden gate, I surprised her with a stop here. If only the bumps in the presidio hadn't woken her up, it would have been a better surprise!

I've never really ate crepes before. I've always considered them just dessert burritos haha. So I copied her order and got a crepe with nutella, whip cream and strawberries. 

It was like $10 for both of us. They were pretty good. Definitely nice to have a good combination & balance of fresh fruit with whipped cream and the creamy, cocoa flavored nutella. The crepe was a nice mix of crispy and chewy.

After coming here, a few people hit me up and gave me other suggestions. Crepes are cool, if I'm in the area again, I'll stop by. It's just so out of the way and inconvenient. I will recommend this place though!
author: Daniel D.

description:
YUMMMMMMMMM!
and it's inside a japanese supermarket, buy some goodies!!
author: Angela D.

description:
I have always read yelp reviews, but have never actually written one.  

Genki Crepes..... you will be my first review!

When I first moved to the city and found you about 4 years ago, I seriously had your #17 with any type of cheese at least twice a week.  The teriyaki beef, green onions, cheese and that sauce is the shiiiiiii.... High or sober,  #17 is a winner.  I think there was one week that I had a savory crepe 4 days in a row... alternating between the sausage one and the good ole # 17.

$10 limit on all cards.... Get some snacks.  

No hot sauce... go to Quickly across the street and get some there.
author: Brandon T.

description: Best dessert crepes I've ever had. My gf and I ordered a mixed fruit crepe and added some Nutella spread to share. We ended up getting a crepe each because the first bite was so delicious. We didn't want to share after that. The crepe was very yummy and chewy.
author: Hailey V.

description: I've heard a lot about Genki over the years so I just had to try it out after lunch at King of Thai.  Good crepes, but something about it didn't quite live up to the hype for me.  I ordered the kiwi with strawberry ice cream which was an overall winner, but there were a couple minor complaints- the kiwi was not quite ripe (so a little bitter) and I thought that my crepe was a bit overcooked.  Bonus points for all the Japanese imported snacks and candies that make me feel like I'm in Japan again!
author: Jeff C.

description:
I've got to hand it to Genki---they have quite the crowd ganging up on them and their dessert products every time I've been here. There's got to be something to it, a secret they hold that brings in their loyal fans in hordes and droves at nighttime. However, I just don't get it.

Clement street is a food haven indeed. With P. Orgasmica on your street, you'll be salivating to eat more after a dinner experience within 4 blocks of every cardinal direction of Clement. I just don't understand why Genki picks up the dessert seekers?

It feels like a sweatshop here. I feel like the cash register chick is useless. It's like if you get creative on the cash register chick, she shuts down. I wanted a milkshake that was Nutella in origin, and she just said "it's impossible". I thought that was funny so I said "your staff is incapable of making it...or?", she says: "Yes! That's what the problem is, it's impossible."

Many's the Asian that this place attracts. I know Asians love to eat. But I'm afraid that just because there are throngs present doesn't mean the food is good----just that they all followed each other to the same place with little individual opinion or will to contradict what the group has decided to do. I suppose it's a cultural idiosyncrasy, and we all have them, no? But, I feel like, if interrogated individually, most of the Asian patrons might say "I honestly don't really get why my friends go bonkers for the Denny's style desserts served here, but I just want to hang out with and chill with my friends, so it's fine."

I've got to give it three stars though, because I enjoyed a pretty tasty mocha milkshake and was highly amused at the lack of space to queue up inside, as well, of course, as the robotic cash register chick. It's worth it to look through the convenience store, though. You might find some interesting products to experiment with at home while you wait for whatever non-Nutella milkshake you've ordered.
author: Davey R.

description:
Must. Go. Back. To get. Another. Crepe. But with extra Nutella :]

After stuffing ourselves silly at Q's down the street, we came here for dessert. Instantly, the smells makes your mouth water and all the fun little asian knick-knacks invite you to walk around the market. They have those little toy machines where you put a dollar in and get some sort of little Disney themed toy to hang on your phone. They also have an interesting selection of foreign candy and drinks.

But the main reason why anyone comes here must be the crepes. What I love about these crepes is that the actual crepe itself is nice and crispy, not soft like many other places. It's easy to hold and share. I got the Nutella with bananas and strawberries. It was good, but definitely needed more Nutella and bananas. Not sure if there weren't too many because we came close to closing, but the crepe would have been much better with more filling. They also have a custard filling which I must try. They actually have lots of crepes that I HAVE to try. Next time I'm in the Ctiy, I will make sure to stop by here.

btw, this is like a little market. So there's really no place to sit except two lawn chairs near the door. Take your snack outside or go for a stroll down the street.
author: Jacqueline N.

description: Highly recommend the cheesecake+whipcream+blueberry sauce.  Great amount of food for the price.  My friend enjoyed the chocolate icecream with cheesecake.
author: Donte J.

description:
Crepes and interesting Japanese snacks and candy is why you come here. 

My boy's favorite crepe is nutella with strawberry ice cream. I am partial to the beef sukiyaki =) 

While you wait for your crepe, definitely peruse the aisles. I've actually ended up here more than once to buy some last minute bday gifts for my nieces.
